THE OHIO STATE UNIVERSITY
TELECOMMUNICATIONS CENTER WOSU TELEVISION
Richard B. Hull, Executive Director 2470 North Star Road
Columbus 21, Ohio
January 5, 1962
Miss Betty MeIIvane
National Association of Educational Broadcasters
13^6 Connecticut Ave., N.W.
Washington 6, D. C.
Dear Betty:
Finally back at the office on January 3rd (late arrival due
to weather problems at London airport), with your special delivery letter
in re Walter Stone1^ request arriving late that afternoon.
I did some investigation and then called Stone directly,
since l had some other matters to discuss with him.
My advice: that the NAEB would take no position on this
bill unless forced to by Oren Harris. The bill, I felt, was responsive
to the concerns which followed the quiz hearings and more timely when
proposed than presently. The bill is unpopular with the FCC who regards
this as its area of administrative concern.
New legislation, I suggested to Stone, which would create
a national governmental board of review with a broader purview in tele«*»
communications might have merit, but the Ashley bill, I felt, would
require almost complete rewriting to be acceptable politically or other¬
wise.
I told Stone I did not share the view of NETRC or JCET that
a citizen*s commission would fill this need—that such efforts had been
tried repeatedly by a number of groups or agencies including the Fund
for Adult Education (early in its history—the only outcome, incidentally,
was OMNIBUS). However, a presidential commission which would be a real
or quasi agency of government is quite a different thing.
Sincerely,
Richard B. Hull, Director
